summary: This document is a chain of emails from September 3, 2019, between the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. The OCME requests a specific list of documents the prosecution wants withheld from disclosure and seeks to discuss a document they were asked to destroy but have deactivated. The prosecution attaches a draft FBI interview report from August 12, 2019.

persons.name: General Counsel Office of Chief Medical Examiner
persons.context: The sender/author of the initial email, requesting a list of specific documents from the U.S. Attorney's Office that should not be disclosed and seeking a discussion about a document requested for destruction.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of the final email in the chain, who attaches a draft FBI interview report dated August 12, 2019, and confirms a request for the OCME to destroy its copy of that report.

connections.person1: General Counsel Office of Chief Medical Examiner
connections.person2: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: Engaged in email correspondence regarding document handling and disclosure requests in the Epstein case, specifically concerning a draft FBI interview report.

events.title: FBI Interview Report Draft Created

events.title: Email Correspondence Regarding Document Handling
events.description: The OCME and U.S. Attorney's Office exchange emails to schedule a call and discuss requests for non-disclosure and destruction of a specific document (the draft FBI interview report).

Jurisdiction of the U.S. Attorney's Office involved in the correspondence.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office requested the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) not to disclose certain documents and to destroy its copy of a draft FBI interview report dated August 12, 2019.

The OCME is pushing back by requesting a specific list of the documents the prosecution wants withheld and seeks to discuss the document requested for destruction, noting they have already 'deactivated' it.

The email chain reveals ongoing coordination and potential tension between investigative/prosecutorial bodies and the medical examiner's office regarding evidence handling in the Epstein case shortly after his death.
